ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: Less than 1
Zero
I spent 0 hours outside of class.
2 hours
less than an hour, just some readings to prep for seminar speaker
1 or less

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Very good - very engaging and interesting speakers and topics
Exceptional course. The quality of the speakers was astounding and the format lent itself well to thoughtful discussions and Q&A.

Strengths: Introducing students to global health issues Hearing from professionals in the field Weaknesses: Developing our own ideas - it seemed promising in the beginning where we would discuss with each other and share, but that stopped. Some of the lectures were very technical and the message was lost.

I really like the course in theory, but in execution some of the topics/speakers weren't quite up to expectations. Also, it was blatantly obvious to a lot of us that people scanned into the code and left before the lectures started. Simply don't make the code available until the end of the lecture to ensure attendance.
Good base of knowledge regarding possibilities of work and careers in Global Health.

I liked the majority of the speakers a lot and was impressed with the caliber of people that came to speak with us. I liked when opportunities were offered to network with the speakers. My one suggestion - do the QR code at the end, or during class. I like the QR code in general, it made attendance easy, but some people would just scan the code and then leave, which defeated the purpose.
Personally I wished there were more speakers that focused on infectious disease. For the EMD students there was only 1 speaker over the whole semester that really focused on our interests.

Coming from the Wall Street, I've come to the conclusion that public health people need to learn to present their materials better. This is a serious issue that public health experts can't effectively disseminate the information or educate others. Everyone in the field should take some basic presentation course. Slides are not your summary notes. They are visual effects to make your points. Don't use small fonts. Don't show many pieces of information at the same time. Show one line at a time. Public health people must learn to sell their products better!
Very interesting speakers each week. I liked the opportunities for breakfast/dinner with the speakers

The timing of this course was terrible--Thursday night after a long day/week, and an almost two hour period before things were due on Friday was really challenging. While some of the speakers were incredible, I would have gotten so much more out of it if it was framed as a dinner event, or maybe on a different night of the week. Additionally, I think more emphasis throughout the course should have been placed on the many challenges of working in global health (I've worked in global health in the past and it's not all success stories)
It met too frequently. Being a seminar, biweekly would've been easier for students to attend and participate in discussion.
Excellent course- loved the array of speakers we had and the various research we were able to learn about.

Strengths is that we were able to see various public health actors with various backgrounds. Weakness is if a particular week had a topic you weren't interested in yet you still had to go. Or some speakers were simply not interesting

Nice overview of global health topics. I felt the seminar was general and thus not particularly geared toward any school or program. Therefore, some presentations were more engaging and interesting than others.
Most of the invited speakers came from a very clinical point of view. The concepts were very broad and rarely went deep. Honestly quite disappointed.
Not a whole lot of engagement from the audience. However, it was nice that we got to learn about a broad array of global health topics from very knowledgeable speakers.

I was impressed by many of the speakers and the course instructors individually, and enjoyed the structure of the course. However, I was very disappointed in the lack of self-criticism and lack and anti-colonialist lens present in the course. I have shied away from global health because, as a student with an anthropology background, I am very hesitant about pursuing an field in which western-based aid workers engage in work in the global south without a solid analysis of the power dynamics involved and the history of colonialism's impact. I was hoping to find this analysis present in Yale's global health program, and was extremely disappointed. I am considering dropping the global health concentration as a result, not because I did not enjoy this class and its speakers - I very much did - but because I don't believe I can study in a program that doesn't feel it necessary to give its intro level students a more solidly self-critical and cautious background.
enjoyable

Maybe shouldn't be a requirement for PH students in global health. Very elementary public health concepts discussed that seemed more helpful for med/nursing students. Limited discussion. Q/A and discussion are different.
Could use more diverse speakers and a session on maternal child health
Discussed many aspects of global health and appealed to the interests of students in differing fields

This course was not a useful use of my time. I often felt like it was geared toward people who had no exposure to public health. As an MPH student I did not learn anything new. In fact, I feel as it should not be a requirement if you have any global health exposure. It was quite unenjoyable, unfortunately.
Strenths: broad overview of global health and its major areas. Weaknesses: not all areas are touched on and some speakers were not good presenters.
Great speakers from various fields, however there was potential for discussion as in group breakouts or smaller group activities
great variety of guest speakers
The first few lectures covered information that most students studying health at the graduate level have already been exposed to.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Mike was excellent. The speaker lineup he arranged was outstanding with leaders from a variety of settings in global health.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Since this was a seminar course there were multiple instructors. All were enthusiastic, well prepared speakers who delivered engaging presentations

Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  I really liked him! He has so much interesting global health experience and brought in incredibly interesting speakers. He really cares about this work and made the class interesting for us.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  He brought in great speakers throughout the semester.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Did a fantastic job of brining in high-power, knowledgeable individuals who have worked towards shaping the fields of global health and research.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  I very much enjoyed the instructors and the speakers in the course.
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  Very nice and pleasant to have as the instructor
Instructor: Michael Skonieczny  The speakers were interesting and informative. He seemed very approachable.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in public health (not just global health). I may sneak in the back in the future just to listen to more speakers. Wonderful experience!

This is the class you have to go to for global health. You hear every week from a different lecturer. Every week. There wasn't one that was skipped, so if you are planning on taking a seminar just to look good on your transcript and not go, this is not the one. However, because of the QR code being outside of the classroom, many people did just scan it and leave with no apparent repercussions. The lectures are very long and there is not very much interaction. There is also no food and it is during dinner time.
A requirement you have to get through. Sometimes interesting, hopefully they reassess the talks that are given each year to ensure quality.

Required seminar for the Global Health track. Well run basic level seminar delving into different topics pertaining to global health and highlighting work from public health researchers/public figures in global health.
I enjoyed this course. It was very interesting.
Great opportunity to hear from people working in the field of global health!
It will help you understand what public health practice on the global level looks like - from funding to disease etiology.

This course provides an interesting opportunity to hear from and learn about researchers and professionals in the field of global health, how they got there, and what they are doing to positively impact populations.
it's a requirement so no way around it for the global health concentration but it's a fun seminar when the speaker is engaging and you are interested in the topic.
If interested in a wide range of global health topics, this course would be a good recommendation.

I believe I answered that above - the course was interesting and informative, but missing essential subject matter I think is necessary in any good program training western individuals to work in the global south.
Worth taking
Great comprehensive overview of global public health topics and issues! Very glad to have taken this course.
Good way to learn about issues in global health from current global health leaders
This course could use some serious revamping. I would not recommend it to my peers.
A good intro to global health issues and strategies, as well as the major players in the field. You will get hungry so bring a snack!
It's a great course to hear about many possible field of work within global health
great insight to global health whether you are interested in the field or not.
